channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: In ‘Brexit’ Speech, Theresa May Outlines Clean Break for U.K.
item.media:description: The Tower of London on Sunday. Brexit supporters have argued that leaving the European Union will provide new trading opportunities.
item.description: In long-awaited remarks, the British prime minister emphasized regaining control of immigration, even if it means losing E.U. trading advantages.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Suspect in Istanbul Rampage on New Year’s Is Captured, Turkey Says
item.media:description: The suspect in the New Year’s Day attack in Istanbul, Turkey, was arrested on Monday.
item.description: The semiofficial Anadolu news agency said the man, Abdulgadir Masharipov, had been captured alive along with four others in the Esenyurt district of Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: As Trump Era Arrives, a Sense of Uncertainty Grips the World
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump in the Trump Tower lobby on Monday. His remarks in a string of interviews have escalated tensions with China and infuriated allies.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: Having made contradictory comments, President-elect Donald J. Trump has many nations wondering about his policies. But there’s also a sense that his words should not be taken too literally.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Justin Trudeau’s Family Vacation on Aga Khan’s Island Leads to Ethics Inquiry
item.media:description: Canada’s prime minister, Justin Trudeau, in Ottawa last month. Two conflict-of-interest inquiries threaten to tarnish the image of Mr. Trudeau, who has promised to conduct politics in a transparent manner.
item.description: The conflict-of-interest investigation and another involving a political fund-raiser threaten to tarnish Mr. Trudeau’s image.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Venezuela Issues New Bank Notes Because of Hyperinflation
item.media:description: Exchanging old notes for new ones at a bank in Caracas, Venezuela, on Monday.
item.description: The move, which has been surrounded by chaos for over a month, is meant to lighten the load for Venezuelans who must carry around bags of cash.
item.dc:creator: ANA VANESSA HERRERO and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Egyptian Court Blocks Plan to Transfer Two Islands to Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: Celebrations erupted in the courtroom when the verdict was announced.
item.description: The verdict is widely expected to further shake, but not break, the strained ties between Cairo and its main financial backer.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Antiaircraft Weapons Again Open Fire in Tehran
item.description: The authorities in Iran said the target was a camera drone, the second such incident in a month.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Nigerian Jet Mistakenly Bombs Refugee Camp, Killing Scores
item.media:description: The aftermath of Tuesday’s bombing at a camp for displaced people in Rann, Nigeria.
item.description: The bombing struck a government-run camp in Rann, near the Cameroonian and Chadian borders, an area where Boko Haram had recently increased attacks.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Is Called Off After Nearly 3 Years
item.media:description: Technicians aboard the Fugro Equator, a ship searching for the remains of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, as it docked in Fremantle, Australia, in May.
item.media:credit: David Dare Parker for The New York Times
item.description: The decision ends the deep-sea scouring of the southern Indian Ocean, ensuring that one of the great aviation mysteries will remain unsolved for the foreseeable future.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Akhilesh Yadav, Indian Politician, Wins Right to Use Bicycle as Election Symbol
item.media:description: Supporters of the politician Akhilesh Yadav celebrating in Lucknow, India, on Monday, after the decision by the election commission. Party symbols often matter more to voters than the candidates’ names do.
item.media:credit: Deepak Gupta/Hindustan Times, via Getty Images
item.description: A panel ruled that Mr. Yadav’s father, a fellow Uttar Pradesh politician with whom he was in dispute, could choose from symbols like a toffee, a pressure cooker and ice cream.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: What in the World: China’s Poplar Trees: A Spring Nuisance That Snows White Fluff
item.media:description: Each spring, poplar trees blanket China’s cities with balls of fluff that can clog car radiators and disrupt traffic.
item.description: Poplar trees blanket the country with balls of fuzz, which irritate people’s eyes and even disrupt traffic. The government has resorted to drastic measures to stop the fluff.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and EMILY FENG

item.title: Challenges Await Antonio Tajani, the European Parliament’s New President
item.media:description: Antonio Tajani, center, was congratulated by members of the European Parliament after being elected the parliament’s president on Tuesday in Strasbourg, France.
item.description: Mr. Tajani was elected president of the European Parliament as the organization confronts tests to its relevance.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Libyan’s Rendition Case Can Move Forward, British Supreme Court Rules
item.media:description: Abdel Hakim Belhaj, center, in 2011 in Tripoli, Libya. He claims he was abducted and tortured by the American and British intelligence services.
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.description: The court’s decision overturned an earlier High Court ruling that said Abdel Hakim Belhaj could not sue the British government or a former foreign secretary.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Trump Can’t Renegotiate Iran Nuclear Deal, Rouhani Says
item.description: The president of Iran said the deal could not be modified, in part because it was also signed by Britain, China, France, Germany and Russia.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Veteran Times Reporter Denied Entry to Turkey
item.description: The action against Rod Nordland, a longtime foreign correspondent, appeared to be part of a broader crackdown against the domestic and foreign press.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Putin Says Accusations in Trump Dossier Are ‘Clearly Fake’
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin on Tuesday. He accused the departing United States administration of trying to undermine President-elect Donald J. Trump.
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia dismissed the allegations in a political memo and said the effort to compile such a document was further evidence of the political decay of the West
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: European Court Orders Russia to Pay U.S. Families Whose Adoptions It Blocked
item.description: Russia said it would appeal the ruling of the European Court of Human Rights within the next three months, but it could ignore the decision outright.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Pendant Found in Nazi Death Camp Ruins May Have Anne Frank Link
item.media:description: This pendant, said to have belonged to Karoline Cohn, was found by archaeologists at the site of Sobibor, the Nazi extermination camp, in eastern Poland.
item.media:credit: Yoram Haimi/Israel Antiquities Authority, via Associated Press
item.description: The item, which belonged to Karoline Cohn, 14, was discovered recently at the Sobibor camp in Poland and is similar to one owned by Anne Frank.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: 4 Quotes From Theresa May’s Speech and What They Mean
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain outlined plans on leaving the European Union in a speech in London on Tuesday.
item.description: The prime minister’s remarks on exiting the European Union were her first public outline of how Britain plans to leave the bloc.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Saulx-les-Chartreux Journal: Life on the Farm Draws Some French Tired of Urban Rat Race
item.media:description: Guilain Vergé, left, and Elisabeth Lavarde worked at a farm near Saulx-les-Chartreux, outside Paris, on Dec. 6, 2016.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: In towns like Saulx-les-Chartreux, small-scale farming is driven by a thriving market for organic food.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: German Court Rejects Effort to Ban Neo-Nazi Party
item.media:description: From left, Peter Marx, a leading member of the National Democratic Party; Peter Richter, a lawyer for the party; and Frank Franz, the chairman of the party, on Tuesday at the Federal Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, Germany. States had submitted a petition to ban the party in 2013.
item.description: Germany’s highest court said that the far-right National Democratic Party did not pose sufficient danger to democracy even though its principles violate the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Suspect in Istanbul Nightclub Attack Confesses, Officials Say
item.media:description: Turkish special forces officers at Police Headquarters in Istanbul on Tuesday.
item.description: Abdulgadir Masharipov, an Uzbek citizen born in 1983, received help in the attack, done “in the name of ISIS,” the governor of the city said at a news conference.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: U.S. Ambassadors in Asia Make Final Plea for Dead Trans-Pacific Trade Pact
item.media:description: Customers lining up outside an Apple store in Tokyo. The Trans-Pacific Partnership would have set new terms and standards for trade for the United States and 11 other Pacific Rim nations, including Japan.
item.description: Max Baucus, the ambassador to China, and five others told Congress in an open letter that the United States should not cede its position in Asia-Pacific trade to China.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Road to Recovery After Concussion Leads to Australian Open
item.media:description: Casey Dellacqua at the 2015 China Open, where she fell and hit her head. Her next memory was of being in a Beijing hospital.
item.description: Casey Dellacqua, who fell and hit her head during the 2015 China Open, missed nine months of competition while living in a “constant world of drowsiness.”
item.dc:creator: SIMON CAMBERS

item.title: Northern Ireland, Forced by Sinn Fein, Sets Early Election in Shadow of ‘Brexit’
item.description: Sinn Fein, the Catholic party that forced the early vote, appears to hope that worries over leaving the European Union will weaken its unionist rivals.
item.dc:creator: SINEAD O’SHEA

item.title: For Trump, Three Decades of Chasing Deals in Russia
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump, a co-owner of the Miss Universe contest at the time, at an after-party for the 2013 pageant in Moscow. He also used the visit to Moscow to discuss development deals.
item.description: Donald J. Trump, and eventually his children, repeatedly sought business in Russia as far back as 1987, in a variety of ventures. But none got off the ground.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN TWOHEY and STEVE EDER

item.title: As Inauguration Nears, Trump Keeps World Leaders on Edge
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday at Trump Tower in New York. He has recently criticized NATO, the European Union and the One China policy.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: The president-elect drew global responses after an interview with The Wall Street Journal and with two European newspapers, Bild and The Times of London.
item.dc:creator: ROGENE JACQUETTE

item.title: 5 Killed at BPM Festival in Mexico
item.description: An attacker was sought after opening fire during an international electronic music festival in Playa Del Carmen, and tourists were among the dead, officials said.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Cold War Jitters Resurface as U.S. Marines Arrive in Norway
item.media:description: United States Marines arriving on Monday in Norway, where their military exercises will involve learning to fight in Arctic temperatures.
item.description: Despite being generally welcomed, the presence of the Marines — shown on Norwegian television dragging their suitcases through the snow — also provoked concerns.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Global Health: How the Response to Zika Failed Millions
item.media:description: A 4-month-old baby with microcephaly being examined in Brazil this month. Her mother was infected with the Zika virus while she was pregnant.
item.description: One year after the W.H.O. declared a public health emergency, experts reflect on the response to the virus and find many aspects wanting.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Burnley Journal: U.K. Police Look to Young Recruits to Help Shed an Image as ‘Male, Pale and Stale’
item.media:description: After gaining entry to an apartment in Burnley, England, Constable Francesca Wheatley, right, and Constable Nagine Ahmed inspected a small quantity of cannabis that the tenant said was for personal use.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A program, similar to Teach for America, places university graduates for two years in some of the country’s most troubled areas, with a focus on diversifying the police corps.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: World’s 8 Richest Have as Much Wealth as Bottom Half, Oxfam Says
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Bill Gates, Amancio Ortega Gaona, Warren E. Buffett, Carlos Slim Helú, Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, Lawrence J. Ellison, Michael R. Bloomberg.
item.media:credit: NYT; Reuters; Reuters; Reuters; Getty; European Pressphoto Agency; Getty; AP
item.description: The eight, all men, hold as much combined wealth as the 3.6 billion people in the bottom half, the charity said in a report that highlighted inequality.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: President Rodrigo Duterte of Philippines Criticized Over Martial Law Warning
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte inspected troops at a celebration of the Philippine armed forces in December. Mr. Duterte has made a bloody campaign against drug dealers and users a central part of his administration.
item.description: One rights activist said that Mr. Duterte was harboring “fascist dreams” after he said that he could impose martial law to curb drug abuse.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Turkish Cargo Plane Crashes Into Village in Kyrgyzstan, Killing Dozens
item.media:description: Emergency crews near Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, on Monday after a cargo jet crashed on approach to the airport, killing dozens of people.
item.description: The plane was approaching the airport in Bishkek, the capital, when it struck a cluster of houses.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Samsung Heir Faces Arrest on Charges of Bribing South Korea’s President
item.media:description: Jay Y. Lee, vice chairman of Samsung, in Seoul, South Korea, last week. A special prosecutor is seeking to arrest him on charges of bribing President Park Geun-hye.
item.description: Jay Y. Lee, the de facto head of Samsung, is accused of ordering large payments to the family of President Park Geun-hye’s confidante and two foundations.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Kitsch vs. Antiques: Tourist Trade Threatens Portobello Market
item.media:description: Once an arcade with 200 antique dealers, the World Famous Portobello Market is now an open-plan gallery selling mass-produced souvenirs.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: Hordes of visitors descend on the famous stalls in the Notting Hill area of London, but many come for the cheap souvenirs rather than the valuable vintage goods.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT REYBURN

item.title: Editorial: French Fraternity and Migrants
item.media:description: The olive farmer Cedric Herrou leaving court in Nice, France, this month, next to a supporter holding a placard reading “He opened the door to you, he heated you, he comforted you, he must be imprisoned.”
item.description: A handful of citizens moved by basic humanity are risking arrest for offering aid.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Trump Threatens a Good Neighbor
item.description: Mexico must be prepared to shed its historically conciliatory stance.
item.dc:creator: ENRIQUE KRAUZE

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Israel as the Lights Go Out
item.media:description: Elon Moreh, an Israeli settlement in the West Bank, seen from the Palestinian village of Azmout, last week.
item.description: In America, there is always a domestic political reason for not doing the right thing on Israel-Palestine.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
